name: flexTeaching
tagline: Use rstudio flexdashboards to create random stats assignments
body:
### What is flexTeaching?
[flexTeaching](https://github.com/richarddmorey/flexTeaching) is a teaching tool for creating and deploying lessons and assignments that include personalized random data, based on a random seed based on their student ID. It is based on [Rstudioâ€™s shiny](http://shiny.rstudio.com) and [flexsdashboard](http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com/flexdashboard/index.html).

![The "summaries" assignment, with solutions](http://learnbayes.org/images/flexTeach/flexTeach2_tn.png)

### See it in action
Go to the solutions [demo](http://richarddmorey.shinyapps.io/test/solve.Rmd), choose the "summaries" assignment, and uncheck "Hide answers?". Notice that the solutions appear within the document. Now change the student ID or the secret, and see how the data set, and the solutions, change. If you change the student ID or secret back to what it was, you will see that the data and solutions are the same as they were.

### How does it work?
A student goes to the data download interface ([demo](http://richarddmorey.shinyapps.io/test/download.Rmd)) and selects an assignment. They then enter their unique ID (e.g., student ID). They can then read the assignment and download a randomly-generated data set that is specific to them. The data is generated using a secret that the student does not know, but markers do.

One the student has turned in their assignment, a marker can then go to the solution interface ([demo](http://richarddmorey.shinyapps.io/test/solve.Rmd)) and input the student's ID number, along with the secret that was used to generate the data. If they uncheck "Hide answers?" they can view the assignment along with the solutions specific to that student.

The students can also access the solutions interface ([demo](http://richarddmorey.shinyapps.io/test/solve.Rmd)), but because they don't know the secret they do not get the solutions to *their* data set. But they can download a new data set and see the solutions for that data set. By changing the ID and the secret in the solutions interface, they can obtain as many practice data sets as they like.

### How can I try making my own assignment?

Making an new assignment is easy.

#### 1. Get the repository
If you know how to use GitHub, fork the repository. If not, download the repository and unzip the file.

#### 2. Create a new assignment
Duplicate the folder `app/assignments/summaries` in the same folder; call it anything else, say, "summaries2".

#### 3. Install the necessary packages
Run this line of code in R/RStudio:

     install.packages(c("shiny","rmarkdown","stargazer","broom","xtable",
     "flexdashboard","digest","base64enc","haven","xlsx",
     "lubridate"), dep=TRUE)

#### 4. Start the flexTeaching app
Open `solve.Rmd` in RStudio and click "Knit" or "Run document" (depending on what it says in your interface).

![Click "Knit" or "Run document"](http://learnbayes.org/images/flexTeach/run.png)

You should see your "new" assignment listed in the assignment box. Selecting it should give you the same output as the summaries" assignment.

#### 5. Edit the data generating function
Open `assignments.R` in your new assignment's folder, and edit the `getData` function so that it returns a `data.frame` with random. Do not change the `set.seed.alpha` line.

#### 6. Edit the assignment markdown
Open `assignments.Rmd` file. On code chunks that should only be output when solutions are requested, use the arguments `eval=solutions` or `include=solutions`. The former does not run the chunk, the latter runs it but does not make the results visible.

#### 7. Restart the interface
Open `solve.Rmd` in RStudio and click "Knit" or "Run document". You should be able to see the changes you made to your assignment. Uncheck the "Hide answers?" box to see the solutions.

#### 8. Publish on a shiny server
To make your assignments visible and usable by others, you must publish them on a shiny server such as (shinyapps.io) or one set up by your institution.
